title: UE Assembly members schooled on District Assembly concept
text:
Politics | 15 October 2015 17:00 CET UE Assembly members schooled on District Assembly concept By GNA 
Bolgatanga, Oct 15, GNA - Selected Assembly members in the Upper East Region have participated in a three-day capacity-building workshop on the District Assembly concept and its operationalization. 
The training programme, was organized by the Savannah Accelerated Development Authority's Millennium Village Projects (SADA-MVP), for assembly men and women within the jurisdiction of the SADA -MVP's communities in the Builsa South District in the Upper East Region, Mamprugu Moaduri and the West Mamprusi Districts in the Northern Region. 
It was aimed at refreshing the minds of the participants on the decentralization concept, and to help champion and promote SADA-MVP activities. 
Mr Issahaku Yakubu, the resource person for the workshop, said the lack of requisite knowledge of Assembly members on the operationalization of the Assembly concept made it difficult for them to function effectively, particularly in the areas of scrutinizing Assembly budgets and project documents. 
The participants were taken through topics such as the functions of the District Assembly, Composition of District Assembly, functions of Urban/Town/Zonal /Area Councils, Functions of Unit Committees, Structure of the Assembly, The Committee system of the District Assembly, Types of Committees and Model Standing Orders.. 
Mr Yakubu urged them to keep abreast with the legal instruments of the Assembly concept, to empower themselves and enable them contribute effectively at Assembly sittings. 
He regretted the lack of substructures in many of the districts in the country, and urged the participants to advocate for the creation of the substructures since they were the means for full and effective participation at the grassroots. 
'It is critical for Assembly members to work effectively with the Unit committees to monitor contractors, draw community action plans and to use the community action plans to advocate for development instead of always relying solely on the District Assembly,' he told the participants. 
Schooling them on their roles and responsibilities, the resource person mentioned that as assembly members, they represented their constituents and were expected to present their concerns to the Assemblies and vice versa. 
He said they were expected to educate the electorate on Government policies and Assembly programmes and projects, lobby the Assembly for development projects in their electoral areas, participate actively in Assembly and Sub-Committee meetings, liaise with public and private institutions/NGOs to attract resources and assistance, as well as initiate and take part in communal and development activities in their respective communities. 
Mr Edwin Batiir, the Community Mobilization and Institutions Coordinator for SADA MVP, explained that what informed his outfit to organize the programme was the recognition that newly-elected Assembly members needed the requisite knowledge and skills about the operations of the District Assembly, to be able to function effectively for the next four years. 
'It is important to note that the recent election has produced some new representatives for some of our communities; making this capacity building workshop very significant. The new Assembly members will also need to be exposed to the SADA- MVP operations to enable them participates actively in the planning for the development of MVP communities' 
He expressed worry about the lack of requisite knowledge and skills of some of the Assembly members on the operations of the District Assembly, and noted that it was seriously affecting them in their quest to deliver at the Assembly level and make positive impact. 
GNA
